channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Haitians, After Perilous Journey, Find Door to U.S. Abruptly Shut
item.media:description: Haitians lined up to sleep at a shelter in Tijuana, Mexico. Some pretend to be Congolese in hopes of receiving better treatment from the Mexican authorities.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: After a trek through Latin America many migrants thought they were just days from entering the United States, but a shift in American policy has left them stranded.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: ‘Doomsday Today in Aleppo’: Assad and Russian Forces Bombard City
item.media:description: The body of a child is pulled from the rubble in al-Marja.
item.description: Repeated airstrikes that destroyed buildings and killed about 100 people came with the threat of a ground invasion, as efforts at the United Nations to revive a truce appeared to collapse.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Egypt Recovers Over 160 Bodies From Sunken Migrant Boat
item.description: The boat was carrying more than 400 people, most young Egyptian men, and the death toll is expected to rise, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: South Korea’s President Has No Easy Options in Dealing with an Aggressive North
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea in Washington in October. Despite the urging of other leaders of the nation, she has refused to talk to North Korea after its nuclear testing.
item.description: Park Geun-hye could pursue her goal of tightening sanctions on North Korea, from which she may face more nuclear provocations, or she could try to engage its government.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Yumingzui Village Journal: On the Verge of Extinction, a Chinese Fishing Village Resists
item.media:description: Xue Qingping, a fisherman in Yumingzui Village, China, drove his boat from the docks into the bay at dusk so he could fish at night.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Officials, who restricted fishing because of a devastated supply, have tried to promote tourism as an alternative. But villagers say tourists are demanding what the sea cannot give.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: An Expert on Chinese Medicine, but No New Age Healer
item.media:description: “Medicine and politics are similar: You don’t blame others, you blame yourself.” PAUL U. UNSCHULD
item.media:credit: Andrea Gjestvang for The New York Times
item.description: Paul U. Unschuld has done more to promote Chinese medicine than perhaps any other Westerner, but he sees it more as a clue to the culture than as an exotic cure.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Police Sex Abuse Case Is Bad News for Mexico’s Leader
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto, center, during Mexico’s Independence Day parade last week in Mexico City. A crackdown he ordered a decade ago when he was governor of Mexico State is under scrutiny.
item.description: An international commission’s call for an investigation into a 2006 crackdown, ordered by Enrique Peña Nieto when he was governor, is a new blow to his presidency.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: 6 Sites Recognized by Britain for Significance to Gay History
item.media:description: Red House, in Aldeburgh, England, where Benjamin Britten and his partner lived from 1957 until Britten’s death in 1976.
item.description: The sites include former homes of Oscar Wilde and Benjamin Britten, and were chosen as part of an effort to commemorate Britain’s gay heritage.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Special Report: Democracy 2016: A Future Haunted by Ghosts of the Past
item.description: Among analysts at a forum organized in Athens by The Times, there was agreement that democracy was in danger, and liberalism even more so.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: U.N. Criticizes Congo for Response to Deadly Unrest
item.description: The high commissioner for human rights blamed the government for using excessive force during political demonstrations and riots that may have killed over 50 people.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Memo From Maiduguri: Boko Haram Rages in Nigeria, but the World’s Eyes Are Elsewhere
item.media:description: Workers provided food for residents at a camp for displaced people in Maiduguri, Nigeria. With villagers from the countryside pouring in, the entire city has become a sprawling refugee camp.
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.description: The militant group, which has pledged allegiance to the Islamic State, has continued its bloody campaign, creating a growing humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Canada Today: Taking the International Stage
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and the Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Thursday. Canada and China are in talks about a possible extradition treaty and exploring a free-trade agreement.
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s debut address to the United Nations General Assembly was well received, even as Canada and China began negotiating an extradition treaty.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Terry Jones of Monty Python Has Dementia, His Family Says
item.media:description: Terry Jones at the Toronto Film Festival in 2012.
item.description: The actor, 74, is best known for his roles in the British comedy troupe and as a director or writer of works like “Life of Brian” and “Monty Python and the Holy Grail.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: Over 300 Civilians Have Been Killed in Yemen Since August, U.N. Says
item.description: Most of the deaths were inflicted by a Saudi-led coalition that supports Yemen’s president, but some blame also was placed on Houthi rebels.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese City Urges Comrades to Do Their Part and Reproduce
item.media:description: Now that all Chinese families are allowed to have two children, Communist Party members in at least one city have been instructed to take the lead and have a second child.
item.description: The appeal by Yichang officials, coming so soon after the end of the national one-child policy, was met with howls of amazement and resentment on social media.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere: For Mocking a Martyr, Chinese Blogger Runs Afoul of Beijing Court
item.description: The court ordered the offender to apologize for a post that compared a Korean War hero to barbecued meat, and his blog has gone offline.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Canada and China Will Enter Trade Talks, Justin Trudeau Says
item.media:description: Premier Li Keqiang of China, left, and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada at a signing ceremony on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Thursday.
item.description: The announcement was the latest of Mr. Trudeau’s efforts to develop stronger ties. He said he hoped to double trade with China by 2025.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood’s Political Arm Wins Seats in Jordan’s Parliament
item.media:description: Officials counted ballots in Amman, Jordan, on Tuesday at a polling station for parliamentary elections.
item.description: Most seats in the lower house were retained by pro-monarchy loyalists, election results showed, but Islamists and women made gains.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Obama Puts Syria at Arm’s Length as Carnage Drags On
item.media:description: President Obama at a luncheon at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. His farewell address that day scarcely mentioned Syria.
item.description: The president scarcely mentioned the war in a farewell address to the United Nations General Assembly, typical of the approach he has taken on the world stage in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Why the World Forgot the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
item.description: In the past, Mahmoud Abbas and Benjamin Netanyahu dominated the United Nations General Assembly, but this year, they were overshadowed by concerns over Syria and ISIS.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Trilobites: In the Wild, Goldfish Turn From Pet to Pest
item.media:description: A goldfish caught by researchers in the Vasse River in Australia. Some fish in the river grow as long as 16 inches and weigh up to four pounds.
item.description: Your pet goldfish may seem tiny and harmless. But in the wild, they can take down entire ecosystems.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Sidelined at the U.N., a Frustrated Taiwan Presses On
item.media:description: Joanne Ou, the director of Taiwan’s United Nations Task Force, at her office in Manhattan this month. Ms. Ou is responsible for efforts to gain greater recognition for Taiwanese.
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times
item.description: China has for decades chipped away at Taiwan’s global standing, but now the island is pushing back with behind-the-scenes diplomacy and soft power.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: With Boeing Deal, Americans Are Coming to Iran
item.description: Boeing technicians, trainers and managers will be the first United States citizens to take up residence in Iran since 1980, when all 140,000 Americans there were forced to leave.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: ‘Fees Must Fall’: Anatomy of the Student Protests in South Africa
item.media:description: The police fired stun grenades and rubber bullets in an attempt to disperse students.
item.description: Protests by university students flared up after a government proposal that university fees could increase as much as 8 percent next year.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Amid New Airstrikes in Syria, an Aid Convoy Arrives
item.media:description: Syrian men removed a baby from the rubble of a destroyed building after an airstrike in Aleppo on Wednesday.
item.description: A procession of trucks carrying supplies for 40,000 people arrived in a Damascus suburb on Thursday, but bombing continued in the rebel-held areas of Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON, NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: After ‘Brexit,’ E.U. Revives Idea of Its Own Joint Military Command
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at a European Union summit meeting in Bratislava, Slovakia, this month.
item.description: The notion of a European military headquarters outside of NATO is back, and the United States now seems quietly supportive of the idea.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Climate Change Threatens World’s Coffee Supply, Report Says
item.media:description: Coffee beans in Dalat, Vietnam.
item.media:credit: David Hagerman for The New York Times
item.description: A new analysis of environmental research has coffee companies and drinkers worried about the future of the product.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Professed Hit Man Tempers Claims of Rodrigo Duterte’s Role in Philippine Killings
item.media:description: Senator Leila de Lima, an outspoken critic of President Rodrigo Duterte’s deadly antidrug campaign in the Philippines, at a news conference in Pasay City on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Joseph Vidal/Philippine Senate, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Under questioning, Edgar Matobato said he did not hear the president order an execution but saw him give orders to a death squad commander.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: U.S. to Step Up Deportations of Haitians Amid Surge at Border
item.media:description: Migrants, including Haitians, waited in May to enter the United States at the San Ysidro crossing that links Tijuana, Mexico, with San Diego.
item.description: The Obama administration said it would fully resume deportations of those without visas, a policy shift that surprised migrant advocates.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Afghanistan Signs Draft Peace Deal With Faction Led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar
item.media:description: People protesting Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the leader of Hezb-i-Islami, in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Thursday.
item.description: The faction, Hezb-i-Islami, agreed to cease hostilities in exchange for government recognition and support for removing sanctions against its leader.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Botched’ Repair to China’s Great Wall Provokes Outrage
item.media:description: The paving over of a stretch of the Great Wall in northeast China has been criticized for effacing the ancient monument’s distinctive features.
item.description: An effort to preserve a stretch of the Great Wall in northeast China has been criticized for erasing distinctive features.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Sinosphere: Lang Lang Is Named New York’s First ‘Cultural Tourism Ambassador’
item.media:description: The Chinese pianist Lang Lang was presented with a personalized double-decker Gray Line bus when he was named New York City’s first “cultural tourism ambassador.”
item.description: With the pianist’s help, the city hopes to entice Chinese visitors to explore parts of the city outside Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Sinosphere: Artist Zeng Fanzhi on the Evolution of His Work and China’s Art Market
item.media:description: Visitors at the opening of “Zeng Fanzhi: Parcours,” the first solo exhibition of his works in Beijing, in front of a painting from his “Masks” series.
item.description: As a major retrospective opens in Beijing, Mr. Zeng discusses traditional Chinese culture, the marketplace and mixing politics and art.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas: Out to Push Palestinian Cause Back to Top of Agenda
item.media:description: There are only so many ways for Mahmoud Abbas to draw attention to his issue — and he has already used many of them.
item.description: As president of the Palestinian Authority, he is not a head of state, a point he is likely to make in an appeal to the United Nations to help make him one.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Iran’s President Accuses U.S. of ‘Lack of Compliance’ on Nuclear Deal
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani, speaking at the United Nations, warned that American credibility would suffer if the United States undercut the accord with “illegal actions.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu: Speaking to an Audience Outside the Hall
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel finds useful foils in his international peers.
item.description: Israel’s prime minister is determined to head off any new effort to try to dictate terms of a settlement of the longstanding conflict with the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s Leader, Opts Not to Deliver U.N. Speech
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro in Porlamar, Venezuela, on Saturday.
item.description: Mr. Maduro did not offer a reason, but his government often cancels engagements and meetings without explanation. The foreign minister will fill in.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: What in the World: Australia Is Not as Down Under as Everyone Thinks It Is
item.description: That map of Australia you have? It’s wrong. And the whole country is going to officially relocate north to correct the error.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: What in the World: In a Lab in Poland, Plastic That Can Crawl
item.description: Hit it with a laser, and a polymer strip at the University of Warsaw will start wriggling like a caterpillar, part of a new class of “soft robots.”
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Opinion: Forget Trump’s Wall: For Mexico, the Election Is About Nafta
item.description: With both candidates bashing free trade, how their anger translates into policy is the big question south of the border.
item.dc:creator: IOAN GRILLO

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on the Syria Cease-Fire
item.description: Recent airstrikes threatened the agreement’s hoped-for success.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: America’s Duty to Take In Refugees
item.description: With 65 million displaced people, we must become a new Ellis Island.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT ARBEITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has also been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
